The', u'resulting etext was compared with a public domain hard copy version of', u'the text.', u'', u'In chapters 24, 89, and 90, we substituted a capital L for the symbol', u'for the British pound, a unit of currency.', u'', u'', u'', u'', u'', u'MOBY DICK; OR THE WHALE ', u'', u'by Herman Melville', u'', u'', u'', u'', u'ETYMOLOGY.', u'', u'(Supplied by a Late Consumptive Usher to a Grammar School)', u'', u'The pale Usher--threadbare in coat, heart, body, and brain; I see him', u'now.  He was ever dusting his old lexicons and grammars, with a queer', u'handkerchief, mockingly embellished with all the gay flags of all the', u'known nations of the world.  He loved to dust his old grammars; it', u'somehow mildly reminded him of his mortality.', u'', u'"While you take in hand to school others, and to teach them by what', u'name a whale-fish is to be called in our tongue leaving out, through', u'ignorance, the letter H, which almost alone maketh the signification', u'of the word, you deliver that which is not true." --HACKLUYT', u'', u'"WHALE. ... Sw. and Dan. HVAL.  This animal is named from roundness', u'or rolling; for in Dan. HVALT is arched or vaulted." --WEBSTER\'S', u'DICTIONARY', u'', u'"WHALE. ... It is more immediately from the Dut. and Ger. WALLEN;', u'A.S. WALW-IAN, to roll, to wallow." --RICHARDSON\'S DICTIONARY', u'', u'KETOS,               GREEK.', u'CETUS,               LATIN.', u'WHOEL,               ANGLO-SAXON.', u'HVALT,               DANISH.', u'WAL,                 DUTCH.', u'HWAL,                SWEDISH.', u'WHALE,               ICELANDIC.', u'WHALE,               ENGLISH.', u'BALEINE,             FRENCH.', u'BALLENA,             SPANISH.', u'PEKEE-NUEE-NUEE,     FEGEE.', u'PEKEE-NUEE-NUEE,     ERROMANGOAN.', u'', u'', u'', u'', u'EXTRACTS (Supplied by a Sub-Sub-Librarian).', u'', u'It will be seen that this mere painstaking burrower and grub-worm of', u'a poor devil of a Sub-Sub appears to have gone through the long', u'Vaticans and street-stalls of the earth, picking up whatever random', u'allusions to whales he could anyways find in any book whatsoever,', u'sacred or profane.  Therefore you must not, in every case at least,', u'take the higgledy-piggledy whale statements, however authentic, in', u'these extracts, for veritable gospel cetology.  Far from it.  As', u'touching the ancient authors generally, as well as the poets here', u'appearing, these extracts are solely valuable or entertaining, as', u"affording a glancing bird's eye view of what has been promiscuously", u'said, thought, fancied, and sung of Leviathan, by many nations and', u'generations, including our own.', u'', u'So fare thee well, poor devil of a Sub-Sub, whose commentator I am.', u'Thou belongest to that hopeless, sallow tribe which no wine of this', u'world will ever warm; and for whom even Pale Sherry would be too', u'rosy-strong; but with whom one sometimes loves to sit, and feel', u'poor-devilish, too; and grow convivial upon tears; and say to them', u'bluntly, with full eyes and empty glasses, and in not altogether', u'unpleasant sadness--Give it up, Sub-Subs!  For by how much the more', u'pains ye take to please the world, by so much the more shall ye for', u'ever go thankless!  Would that I could clear out Hampton Court and', u'the Tuileries for ye!  But gulp down your tears and hie aloft to the', u'royal-mast with your hearts; for your friends who have gone before', u'are clearing out the seven-storied heavens, and making refugees of', u'long-pampered Gabriel, Michael, and Raphael, against your coming.', u'Here ye strike but splintered hearts together--there, ye shall strike', u'unsplinterable glasses!', u'', u'', u'EXTRACTS.', u'', u'"And God created great whales." --GENESIS.', u'', u'"Leviathan maketh a path to shine after him; One would think the deep', u'to be hoary." --JOB.', u'', u'"Now the Lord had prepared a great fish to swallow up Jonah."', u'--JONAH.', u'', u'"There go the ships; there is that Leviathan whom thou hast made to', u'play therein." --PSALMS.', u'', u'"In that day, the Lord with his sore, and great, and strong sword,', u'shall punish Leviathan the piercing serpent, even Leviathan that', u'crooked serpent; and he shall slay the dragon that is in the sea."', u'--ISAIAH', u'', u'"And what thing soever besides cometh within the chaos of this', u"monster's mouth, be it beast, boat, or stone, down it goes all", u'incontinently that foul great swallow of his, and perisheth in the', u'bottomless gulf of his paunch." --HOLLAND\'S PLUTARCH\'S MORALS.', u'', u'"The Indian Sea breedeth the most and the biggest fishes that are:', u'among which the Whales and Whirlpooles called Balaene, take up as', u'much in length as four acres or arpens of land." --HOLLAND\'S PLINY.', u'', u'"Scarcely had we proceeded two days on the sea, when about sunrise a', u'great many Whales and other monsters of the sea, appeared.  Among the', u'former, one was of a most monstrous size. ...  This came towards us,', u'open-mouthed, raising the waves on all sides, and beating the sea', u'before him into a foam." --TOOKE\'S LUCIAN.  "THE TRUE HISTORY."', u'', u'"He visited this country also with a view of catching horse-whales,', u'which had bones of very great value for their teeth, of which he', u'brought some to the king. ...  The best whales were catched in his', u'own country, of which some were forty-eight, some fifty yards long.', u'He said that he was one of six who had killed sixty in two days."', u"--OTHER OR OCTHER'S VERBAL NARRATIVE TAKEN DOWN FROM HIS MOUTH BY", u'KING ALFRED, A.D. 890.', u'', u'"And whereas all the other things, whether beast or vessel, that', u"enter into the dreadful gulf of this monster's (whale's) mouth, are", u'immediately lost and swallowed up, the sea-gudgeon retires into it in', u'great security, and there sleeps." --MONTAIGNE.  --APOLOGY FOR', u'RAIMOND SEBOND.', u'', u'"Let us fly, let us fly!  Old Nick take me if is not Leviathan', u'described by the noble prophet Moses in the life of patient Job."', u'--RABELAIS.', u'', u'"This whale\'s liver was two cartloads." --STOWE\'S ANNALS.', u'', u'"The great Leviathan that maketh the seas to seethe like boiling', u'pan." --LORD BACON\'S VERSION OF THE PSALMS.', u'', u'"Touching that monstrous bulk of the whale or ork we have received', u'nothing certain.  They grow exceeding fat, insomuch that an', u'incredible quantity of oil will be extracted out of one whale."', u'--IBID.  "HISTORY OF LIFE AND DEATH."', u'', u'"The sovereignest thing on earth is parmacetti for an inward bruise."', u'--KING HENRY.', u'', u'"Very like a whale." --HAMLET.', u'', u'"Which to secure, no skill of leach\'s art', u'Mote him availle, but to returne againe', u"To his wound's worker, that with lowly dart,", u'Dinting his breast, had bred his restless paine,', u'Like as the wounded whale to shore flies thro\' the maine."', u'--THE FAERIE QUEEN.', u'', u'"Immense as whales, the motion of whose vast bodies can in a peaceful', u'calm trouble the ocean til it boil." --SIR WILLIAM DAVENANT.  PREFACE', u'TO GONDIBERT.', u'', u'"What spermacetti is, men might justly doubt, since the learned', u'Hosmannus in his work of thirty years, saith plainly, Nescio quid', u'sit." --SIR T. BROWNE.  OF SPERMA CETI AND THE SPERMA CETI WHALE.', u'VIDE HIS V. E.', u'', u'"Like Spencer\'s Talus with his modern flail', u'He threatens ruin with his ponderous tail.', u'...', u"Their fixed jav'lins in his side he wears,", u'And on his back a grove of pikes appears." --WALLER\'S BATTLE OF THE', u'SUMMER ISLANDS.', u'', u'"By art is created that great Leviathan, called a Commonwealth or', u'State--(in Latin, Civitas) which is but an artificial man." --OPENING', u"SENTENCE OF HOBBES'S LEVIATHAN.", u'', u'"Silly Mansoul swallowed it without chewing, as if it had been a', u'sprat in the mouth of a whale." --PILGRIM\'S PROGRESS.', u'', u'"That sea beast', u'Leviathan, which God of all his works', u'Created hugest that swim the ocean stream." --PARADISE LOST.', u'', u'---"There Leviathan,', u'Hugest of living creatures, in the deep', u'Stretched like a promontory sleeps or swims,', u'And seems a moving land; and at his gills', u'Draws in, and at his breath spouts out a sea." --IBID.', u'', u'"The mighty whales which swim in a sea of water, and have a sea of', u'oil swimming in them." --FULLLER\'S PROFANE AND HOLY STATE.', u'', u'"So close behind some promontory lie', u'The huge Leviathan to attend their prey,', u'And give no chance, but swallow in the fry,', u'Which through their gaping jaws mistake the way."', u"--DRYDEN'S ANNUS MIRABILIS.", u'', u'"While the whale is floating at the stern of the ship, they cut off', u'his head, and tow it with a boat as near the shore as it will come;', u'but it will be aground in twelve or thirteen feet water." --THOMAS', u"EDGE'S TEN VOYAGES TO SPITZBERGEN, IN PURCHAS.", u'', u'"In their way they saw many whales sporting in the ocean, and in', u'wantonness fuzzing up the water through their pipes and vents, which', u'nature has placed on their shoulders." --SIR T. HERBERT\'S VOYAGES', u'INTO ASIA AND AFRICA.  HARRIS COLL.', u'', u'"Here they saw such huge troops of whales, that they were forced to', u'proceed with a great deal of caution for fear they should run their', u'ship upon them." --SCHOUTEN\'S SIXTH CIRCUMNAVIGATION.', u'', u'"We set sail from the Elbe, wind N.E. in the ship called The', u"Jonas-in-the-Whale. ...  Some say the whale can't open his mouth, but", u'that is a fable. ... Some years ago--never mind how long', u'precisely--having little or no money in my purse, and nothing', u'particular to interest me on shore, I thought I would sail about a', u'little and see the watery part of the world.  It is a way I have of', u'driving off the spleen and regulating the circulation.  Whenever I', u'find myself growing grim about the mouth; whenever it is a damp,', u'drizzly November in my soul; whenever I find myself involuntarily', u'pausing before coffin warehouses, and bringing up the rear of every', u'funeral I meet; and especially whenever my hypos get such an upper', u'hand of me, that it requires a strong moral principle to prevent me', u'from deliberately stepping into the street, and methodically knocking', u"people's hats off--then, I account it high time to get to sea as soon", u'as I can.  This is my substitute for pistol and ball.  With a', u'philosophical flourish Cato throws himself upon his sword; I quietly', u'take to the ship.  There is nothing surprising in this.  If they but', u'knew it, almost all men in their degree, some time or other, cherish', u'very nearly the same feelings towards the ocean with me.', u'', u'There now is your insular city of the Manhattoes, belted round by', u'wharves as Indian isles by coral reefs--commerce surrounds it with', u'her surf.  Right and left, the streets take you waterward.  Its', u'extreme downtown is the battery, where that noble mole is washed by', u'waves, and cooled by breezes, which a few hours previous were out of', u'sight of land.  Look at the crowds of water-gazers there.', u'', u'Circumambulate the city of a dreamy Sabbath afternoon.  Go from', u'Corlears Hook to Coenties Slip, and from thence, by Whitehall,', u'northward.  What do you see?--Posted like silent sentinels all around', u'the town, stand thousands upon thousands of mortal men fixed in ocean', u'reveries.  Some leaning against the spiles; some seated upon the', u'pier-heads; some looking over the bulwarks of ships from China; some', u'high aloft in the rigging, as if striving to get a still better', u'seaward peep.  But these are all landsmen; of week days pent up in', u'lath and plaster--tied to counters, nailed to benches, clinched to', u'desks.  How then is this?  Are the green fields gone?  What do they', u'here?', u'', u'But look! here come more crowds, pacing straight for the water, and', u'seemingly bound for a dive.  Strange!  Nothing will content them but', u'the extremest limit of the land; loitering under the shady lee of', u'yonder warehouses will not suffice.  No.  They must get just as nigh', u'the water as they possibly can without falling in.  And there they', u'stand--miles of them--leagues.  Inlanders all, they come from lanes', u'and alleys, streets and avenues--north, east, south, and west.  Yet', u'here they all unite.  Tell me, does the magnetic virtue of the', u'needles of the compasses of all those ships attract them thither?', u'', u'Once more.  Say you are in the country; in some high land of lakes.', u'Take almost any path you please, and ten to one it carries you down', u'in a dale, and leaves you there by a pool in the stream.  There is', u'magic in it.  Let the most absent-minded of men be plunged in his', u'deepest reveries--stand that man on his legs, set his feet a-going,', u'and he will infallibly lead you to water, if water there be in all', u'that region.  Should you ever be athirst in the great American', u'desert, try this experiment, if your caravan happen to be supplied', u'with a metaphysical professor.  Yes, as every one knows, meditation', u'and water are wedded for ever.', u'', u'But here is an artist.  He desires to paint you the dreamiest,', u'shadiest, quietest, most enchanting bit of romantic landscape in all', u'the valley of the Saco.  What is the chief element he employs?  There', u'stand his trees, each with a hollow trunk, as if a hermit and a', u'crucifix were within; and here sleeps his meadow, and there sleep his', u'cattle; and up from yonder cottage goes a sleepy smoke.  Deep into', u'distant woodlands winds a mazy way, reaching to overlapping spurs of', u'mountains bathed in their hill-side blue.  But though the picture', u'lies thus tranced, and though this pine-tree shakes down its sighs', u"like leaves upon this shepherd's head, yet all were vain, unless the", u"shepherd's eye were fixed upon the magic stream before him.  Go visit", u'the Prairies in June, when for scores on scores of miles you wade', u'knee-deep among Tiger-lilies--what is the one charm', u'wanting?--Water--there is not a drop of water there!  Were Niagara', u'but a cataract of sand, would you travel your thousand miles to see', u'it?  Why did the poor poet of Tennessee, upon suddenly receiving two', u'handfuls of silver, deliberate whether to buy him a coat, which he', u'sadly needed, or invest his money in a pedestrian trip to Rockaway', u'Beach?  Why is almost every robust healthy boy with a robust healthy', u'soul in him, at some time or other crazy to go to sea?  Why upon your', u'first voyage as a passenger, did you yourself feel such a mystical', u'vibration, when first told that you and your ship were now out of', u'sight of land?  Why did the old Persians hold the sea holy?  Why did', u'the Greeks give it a separate deity, and own brother of Jove?  Surely', u'all this is not without meaning.  And still deeper the meaning of', u'that story of Narcissus, who because he could not grasp the', u'tormenting, mild image he saw in the fountain, plunged into it and', u'was drowned.  But that same image, we ourselves see in all rivers and', u'oceans.  It is the image of the ungraspable phantom of life; and this', u'is the key to it all.', u'', u'Now, when I say that I am in the habit of going to sea whenever I', u'begin to grow hazy about the eyes, and begin to be over conscious of', u'my lungs, I do not mean to have it inferred that I ever go to sea as', u'a passenger.  For to go as a passenger you must needs have a purse,', u'and a purse is but a rag unless you have something in it.  Besides,', u"passengers get sea-sick--grow quarrelsome--don't sleep of nights--do", u'not enjoy themselves much, as a general thing;--no, I never go as a', u'passenger; nor, though I am something of a salt, do I ever go to sea', u'as a Commodore, or a Captain, or a Cook.  I abandon the glory and', u'distinction of such offices to those who like them.  For my part, I', u'abominate all honourable respectable toils, trials, and tribulations', u'of every kind whatsoever.  It is quite as much as I can do to take', u'care of myself, without taking care of ships, barques, brigs,', u'schooners, and what not.  And as for going as cook,--though I confess', u'there is considerable glory in that, a cook being a sort of officer', u'on ship-board--yet, somehow, I never fancied broiling fowls;--though', u'once broiled, judiciously buttered, and judgmatically salted and', u'peppered, there is no one who will speak more respectfully, not to', u'say reverentially, of a broiled fowl than I will.  It is out of the', u'idolatrous dotings of the old Egyptians upon broiled ibis and roasted', u'river horse, that you see the mummies of those creatures in their', u'huge bake-houses the pyramids.', u'', u'No, when I go to sea, I go as a simple sailor, right before the mast,', u'plumb down into the forecastle, aloft there to the royal mast-head.', u'True, they rather order me about some, and make me jump from spar to', u'spar, like a grasshopper in a May meadow.  And at first, this sort of', u"thing is unpleasant enough.  It touches one's sense of honour,", u'particularly if you come of an old established family in the land,', u'the Van Rensselaers, or Randolphs, or Hardicanutes.  And more than', u'all, if just previous to putting your hand into the tar-pot, you have', u'been lording it as a country schoolmaster, making the tallest boys', u'stand in awe of you.  The transition is a keen one, I assure you,', u'from a schoolmaster to a sailor, and requires a strong decoction of', u'Seneca and the Stoics to enable you to grin and bear it.  But even', u'this wears off in time.', u'', u'What of it, if some old hunks of a sea-captain orders me to get a', u'broom and sweep down the decks?  What does that indignity amount to,', u'weighed, I mean, in the scales of the New Testament?  Do you think', u'the archangel Gabriel thinks anything the less of me, because I', u'promptly and respectfully obey that old hunks in that particular', u"instance?  Who ain't a slave?  Tell me that.  Well, then, however the", u'old sea-captains may order me about--however they may thump and punch', u'me about, I have the satisfaction of knowing that it is all right;', u'that everybody else is one way or other served in much the same', u'way--either in a physical or metaphysical point of view, that is; and', u'so the universal thump is passed round, and all hands should rub each', u"other's shoulder-blades, and be content.", u'', u'Again, I always go to sea as a sailor, because they make a point of', u'paying me for my trouble, whereas they never pay passengers a single', u'penny that I ever heard of.  On the contrary, passengers themselves', u'must pay.  And there is all the difference in the world between', u'paying and being paid.  The act of paying is perhaps the most', u'uncomfortable infliction that the two orchard thieves entailed upon', u'us.  But BEING PAID,--what will compare with it?  The urbane activity', u'with which a man receives money is really marvellous, considering', u'that we so earnestly believe money to be the root of all earthly', u'ills, and that on no account can a monied man enter heaven.  Ah! how', u'cheerfully we consign ourselves to perdition!', u'', u'Finally, I always go to sea as a sailor, because of the wholesome', u'exercise and pure air of the fore-castle deck.  For as in this world,', u'head winds are far more prevalent than winds from astern (that is, if', u'you never violate the Pythagorean maxim), so for the most part the', u'Commodore on the quarter-deck gets his atmosphere at second hand from', u'the sailors on the forecastle. But wherefore it was that after having repeatedly smelt the sea', u'as a merchant sailor, I should now take it into my head to go on a', u'whaling voyage; this the invisible police officer of the Fates, who', u'has the constant surveillance of me, and secretly dogs me, and', u'influences me in some unaccountable way--he can better answer than', u'any one else.  And, doubtless, my going on this whaling voyage,', u'formed part of the grand programme of Providence that was drawn up a', u'long time ago.  It came in as a sort of brief interlude and solo', u'between more extensive performances.  I take it that this part of the', u'bill must have run something like this:', u'', u'', u'"GRAND CONTESTED ELECTION FOR THE PRESIDENCY OF THE UNITED STATES.', u'"WHALING VOYAGE BY ONE ISHMAEL.', u'"BLOODY BATTLE IN AFFGHANISTAN."', u'', u'', u'Though I cannot tell why it was exactly that those stage managers,', u'the Fates, put me down for this shabby part of a whaling voyage, when', u'others were set down for magnificent parts in high tragedies, and', u'short and easy parts in genteel comedies, and jolly parts in', u'farces--though I cannot tell why this was exactly; yet, now that I', u'recall all the circumstances, I think I can see a little into the', u'springs and motives which being cunningly presented to me under', u'various disguises, induced me to set about performing the part I did,', u'besides cajoling me into the delusion that it was a choice resulting', u'from my own unbiased freewill and discriminating judgment.', u'', u'Chief among these motives was the overwhelming idea of the great', u'whale himself. Then the wild and distant seas where he rolled his', u'island bulk; the undeliverable, nameless perils of the whale; these,', u'with all the attending marvels of a thousand Patagonian sights and', u'sounds, helped to sway me to my wish.  With other men, perhaps, such', u'things would not have been inducements; but as for me, I am tormented', u'with an everlasting itch for things remote. Such unaccountable masses of shades', u'and shadows, that at first you almost thought some ambitious young', u'artist, in the time of the New England hags, had endeavored to', u'delineate chaos bewitched.  But by dint of much and earnest', u'contemplation, and oft repeated ponderings, and especially by', u'throwing open the little window towards the back of the entry, you at', u'last come to the conclusion that such an idea, however wild, might', u'not be altogether unwarranted.', u'', u'But what most puzzled and confounded you was a long, limber,', u'portentous, black mass of something hovering in the centre of the', u'picture over three blue, dim, perpendicular lines floating in a', u'nameless yeast. But at", u'last all these fancies yielded to that one portentous something in', u"the picture's midst.  THAT once found out, and all the rest were", u'plain.  But stop; does it not bear a faint resemblance to a gigantic', u'fish? even the great leviathan himself?', u'', u"In fact, the artist's design seemed this: a final theory of my own,", u'partly based upon the aggregated opinions of many aged persons with', u'whom I conversed upon the subject. Had not the stranger', u'stood between me and the door, I would have bolted out of it quicker', u'than ever I bolted a dinner.', u'', u'Even as it was, I thought something of slipping out of the window,', u'but it was the second floor back.  I am no coward, but what to make', u'of this head-peddling purple rascal altogether passed my', u'comprehension.  Ignorance is the parent of fear, and being completely', u'nonplussed and confounded about the stranger, I confess I was now as', u'much afraid of him as if it was the devil himself who had thus broken', u'into my room at the dead of night.  In fact, I was so afraid of him', u'that I was not game enough just then to address him, and demand a', u'satisfactory answer concerning what seemed inexplicable in him.', u'', u'Meanwhile, he continued the business of undressing, and at last', u'showed his chest and arms.  As I live, these covered parts of him', u'were checkered with the same squares as his face; his back, too, was', u'all over the same dark squares; he seemed to have been in a Thirty', u"Years' War, and just escaped from it with a sticking-plaster shirt.", u'Still more, his very legs were marked, as if a parcel of dark green', u'frogs were running up the trunks of young palms.  It was now quite', u'plain that he must be some abominable savage or other shipped aboard', u'of a whaleman in the South Seas, and so landed in this Christian', u'country.  I quaked to think of it.  A peddler of heads too--perhaps', u'the heads of his own brothers.  He might take a fancy to', u'mine--heavens! look at that tomahawk!', u'', u'But there was no time for shuddering, for now the savage went about', u'something that completely fascinated my attention, and convinced me', u'that he must indeed be a heathen.  Going to his heavy grego, or', u'wrapall, or dreadnaught, which he had previously hung on a chair, he', u'fumbled in the pockets, and produced at length a curious little', u'deformed image with a hunch on its back, and exactly the colour of a', u"three days' old Congo baby.  Remembering the embalmed head, at first", u'I almost thought that this black manikin was a real baby preserved', u'in some similar manner.  But seeing that it was not at all limber,', u'and that it glistened a good deal like polished ebony, I concluded', u'that it must be nothing but a wooden idol, which indeed it proved to', u'be.  For now the savage goes up to the empty fire-place, and removing', u'the papered fire-board, sets up this little hunch-backed image, like', u'a tenpin, between the andirons.  The chimney jambs and all the bricks', u'inside were very sooty, so that I thought this fire-place made a very', u'appropriate little shrine or chapel for his Congo idol.', u'', u'I now screwed my eyes hard towards the half hidden image, feeling but', u'ill at ease meantime--to see what was next to follow.  First he takes', u'about a double handful of shavings out of his grego pocket, and', u'places them carefully before the idol; then laying a bit of ship', u'biscuit on top and applying the flame from the lamp, he kindled the', u'shavings into a sacrificial blaze.  Presently, after many hasty', u'snatches into the fire, and still hastier withdrawals of his fingers', u'(whereby he seemed to be scorching them badly), he at last succeeded', u'in drawing out the biscuit; then blowing off the heat and ashes a', u'little, he made a polite offer of it to the little negro.  But the', u'little devil did not seem to fancy such dry sort of fare at all; he', u'never moved his lips.  All these strange antics were accompanied by', u'still stranger guttural noises from the devotee, who seemed to be', u'praying in a sing-song or else singing some pagan psalmody or other,', u'during which his face twitched about in the most unnatural manner.', u'At last extinguishing the fire, he took the idol up very', u'unceremoniously, and bagged it again in his grego pocket as', u'carelessly as if he were a sportsman bagging a dead woodcock.', u'', u'All these queer proceedings increased my uncomfortableness, and', u'seeing him now exhibiting strong symptoms of concluding his business', u'operations, and jumping into bed with me, I thought it was high time,', u'now or never, before the light was put out, to break the spell in', u'which I had so long been bound.', u'', u'But the interval I spent in deliberating what to say, was a fatal', u'one.  Taking up his tomahawk from the table, he examined the head of', u'it for an instant, and then holding it to the light, with his mouth', u'at the handle, he puffed out great clouds of tobacco smoke.  The next', u'moment the light was extinguished, and this wild cannibal, tomahawk', u'between his teeth, sprang into bed with me.  I sang out, I could not', u'help it now; and giving a sudden grunt of astonishment he began', u'feeling me.', u'', u'Stammering out something, I knew not what, I rolled away from him', u'against the wall, and then conjured him, whoever or whatever he might', u'be, to keep quiet, and let me get up and light the lamp again.  But', u'his guttural responses satisfied me at once that he but ill', u'comprehended my meaning.', u'', u'"Who-e debel you?"--he at last said--"you no speak-e, dam-me, I', u'kill-e."  And so saying the lighted tomahawk began flourishing about', u'me in the dark.', u'', u'"Landlord, for God\'s sake, Peter Coffin!" shouted I.  "Landlord!', u'Watch!  Coffin!  Angels! save me!"', u'', u'"Speak-e! tell-ee me who-ee be, or dam-me, I kill-e!" again growled', u'the cannibal, while his horrid flourishings of the tomahawk scattered', u'the hot tobacco ashes about me till I thought my linen would get on', u'fire.  But thank heaven, at that moment the landlord came into the', u'room light in hand, and leaping from the bed I ran up to him.', u'', u'"Don\'t be afraid now," said he, grinning again, "Queequeg here', u'wouldn\'t harm a hair of your head."', u'', u'"Stop your grinning," shouted I, "and why didn\'t you tell me that', u'that infernal harpooneer was a cannibal?"', u'', u'"I thought ye know\'d it;--didn\'t I tell ye, he was a peddlin\' heads', u'around town?--but turn flukes again and go to sleep.  Queequeg, look', u'here--you sabbee me, I sabbee--you this man sleepe you--you sabbee?"', u'', u'"Me sabbee plenty"--grunted Queequeg, puffing away at his pipe and', u'sitting up in bed.', u'', u'"You gettee in," he added, motioning to me with his tomahawk, and', u'throwing the clothes to one side.  He really did this in not only a', u'civil but a really kind and charitable way.  I stood looking at him a', u'moment.  For all his tattooings he was on the whole a clean, comely', u"looking cannibal.  What's all this fuss I have been making about,", u"thought I to myself--the man's a human being just as I am: he has", u'just as much reason to fear me, as I have to be afraid of him.', u'Better sleep with a sober cannibal than a drunken Christian.', u'', u'"Landlord," said I, "tell him to stash his tomahawk there, or pipe,', u'or whatever you call it; tell him to stop smoking, in short, and I', u"will turn in with him.  But I don't fancy having a man smoking in bed", u'with me.  It\'s dangerous.  Besides, I ain\'t insured."', u'', u'This being told to Queequeg, he at once complied, and again politely', u'motioned me to get into bed--rolling over to one side as much as to', u'say--I won\'t touch a leg of ye."', u'', u'"Good night, landlord," said I, "you may go."', u'', u'I turned in, and never slept better in my life.', u'', u'', u'', u'']), (u'chapter005', [u'CHAPTER 5', u'', u'Breakfast.', u'', u'', u'I quickly followed suit, and descending into the bar-room accosted', u'the grinning landlord very pleasantly.  I cherished no malice towards', u'him, though he had been skylarking with me not a little in the matter', u'of my bedfellow.', u'', u'However, a good laugh is a mighty good thing, and rather too scarce a', u"good thing; the more's the pity.  So, if any one man, in his own", u'proper person, afford stuff for a good joke to anybody, let him not', u'be backward, but let him cheerfully allow himself to spend and be', u'spent in that way.  And the man that has anything bountifully', u'laughable about him, be sure there is more in that man than you', u'perhaps think for.', u'', u'The bar-room was now full of the boarders who had been dropping in', u'the night previous, and whom I had not as yet had a good look at.', u'They were nearly all whalemen; chief mates, and second mates, and', u'third mates, and sea carpenters, and sea coopers, and sea', u'blacksmiths, and harpooneers, and ship keepers; a brown and brawny', u'company, with bosky beards; an unshorn, shaggy set, all wearing', u'monkey jackets for morning gowns.', u'', u'You could pretty plainly tell how long each one had been ashore.', u"This young fellow's healthy cheek is like a sun-toasted pear in hue,", u'and would seem to smell almost as musky; he cannot have been three', u'days landed from his Indian voyage.  That man next him looks a few', u'shades lighter; you might say a touch of satin wood is in him.  In', u'the complexion of a third still lingers a tropic tawn, but slightly', u'bleached withal; HE doubtless has tarried whole weeks ashore.  But', u'who could show a cheek like Queequeg? which, barred with various', u"tints, seemed like the Andes' western slope, to show forth in one", u'array, contrasting climates, zone by zone.', u'', u'"Grub, ho!" now cried the landlord, flinging open a door, and in we', u'went to breakfast.', u'', u'They say that men who have seen the world, thereby become quite at', u'ease in manner, quite self-possessed in company.  Not always, though:', u'Ledyard, the great New England traveller, and Mungo Park, the Scotch', u'one; of all men, they possessed the least assurance in the parlor.', u'But perhaps the mere crossing of Siberia in a sledge drawn by dogs as', u'Ledyard did, or the taking a long solitary walk on an empty stomach,', u"in the negro heart of Africa, which was the sum of poor Mungo's", u'performances--this kind of travel, I say, may not be the very best', u'mode of attaining a high social polish.  Still, for the most part,', u'that sort of thing is to be had anywhere.', u'', u'These reflections just here are occasioned by the circumstance that', u'after we were all seated at the table, and I was preparing to hear', u'some good stories about whaling; to my no small surprise, nearly', u'every man maintained a profound silence.  And not only that, but they', u'looked embarrassed.  Yes, here were a set of sea-dogs, many of whom', u'without the slightest bashfulness had boarded great whales on the', u'high seas--entire strangers to them--and duelled them dead without', u'winking; and yet, here they sat at a social breakfast table--all of', u'the same calling, all of kindred tastes--looking round as sheepishly', u'at each other as though they had never been out of sight of some', u'sheepfold among the Green Mountains.  A curious sight; these bashful', u'bears, these timid warrior whalemen!', u'', u'But as for Queequeg--why, Queequeg sat there among them--at the head', u'of the table, too, it so chanced; as cool as an icicle.  To be sure I', u'cannot say much for his breeding.  His greatest admirer could not', u'have cordially justified his bringing his harpoon into breakfast with', u'him, and using it there without ceremony; reaching over the table', u'with it, to the imminent jeopardy of many heads, and grappling the', u'beefsteaks towards him.  But THAT was certainly very coolly done by', u"him, and every one knows that in most people's estimation, to do", u'anything coolly is to do it genteelly.', u'', u"We will not speak of all Queequeg's peculiarities here; how he", u'eschewed coffee and hot rolls, and applied his undivided attention to', u'beefsteaks, done rare.  Enough, that when breakfast was over he', u'withdrew like the rest into the public room, lighted his', u'tomahawk-pipe, and was sitting there quietly digesting and smoking', u'with his inseparable hat on, when I sallied out for a stroll.', u'', u'', u'', u'']), (u'chapter006', [u'CHAPTER 6', u'', u'The Street.', u'', u'', u'If I had been astonished at first catching a glimpse of so outlandish', u'an individual as Queequeg circulating among the polite society of a', u'civilized town, that astonishment soon departed upon taking my first', u'daylight stroll through the streets of New Bedford.', u'', u'In thoroughfares nigh the docks, any considerable seaport will', u'frequently offer to view the queerest looking nondescripts from', u'foreign parts.  Even in Broadway and Chestnut streets, Mediterranean', u'mariners will sometimes jostle the affrighted ladies.  Regent Street', u'is not unknown to Lascars and Malays; and at Bombay, in the Apollo', u'Green, live Yankees have often scared the natives.  But New Bedford', u'beats all Water Street and Wapping.  In these last-mentioned haunts', u'you see only sailors; but in New Bedford, actual cannibals stand', u'chatting at street corners; savages outright; many of whom yet carry', u'on their bones unholy flesh.  It makes a stranger stare.', u'', u'But, besides the Feegeeans, Tongatobooarrs, Erromanggoans,', u'Pannangians, and Brighggians, and, besides the wild specimens of the', u'whaling-craft which unheeded reel about the streets, you will see', u'other sights still more curious, certainly more comical.  There', u'weekly arrive in this town scores of green Vermonters and New', u'Hampshire men, all athirst for gain and glory in the fishery.  They', u'are mostly young, of stalwart frames; fellows who have felled', u'forests, and now seek to drop the axe and snatch the whale-lance.', u'Many are as green as the Green Mountains whence they came.  In some', u'things you would think them but a few hours old.  Look there! that', u'chap strutting round the corner.  He wears a beaver hat and', u'swallow-tailed coat, girdled with a sailor-belt and sheath-knife.', u"Here comes another with a sou'-wester and a bombazine cloak.", u'', u'No town-bred dandy will compare with a country-bred one--I mean a', u'downright bumpkin dandy--a fellow that, in the dog-days, will mow his', u'two acres in buckskin gloves for fear of tanning his hands.  Now when', u'a country dandy like this takes it into his head to make a', u'distinguished reputation, and joins the great whale-fishery, you', u'should see the comical things he does upon reaching the seaport.  In', u'bespeaking his sea-outfit, he orders bell-buttons to his waistcoats;', u'straps to his canvas trowsers.  Ah, poor Hay-Seed! how bitterly will', u'burst those straps in the first howling gale, when thou art driven,', u'straps, buttons, and all, down the throat of the tempest.', u'', u'But think not that this famous town has only harpooneers, cannibals,', u'and bumpkins to show her visitors.  Not at all.  Still New Bedford is', u'a queer place.  Had it not been for us whalemen, that tract of land', u'would this day perhaps have been in as howling condition as the coast', u'of Labrador.  As it is, parts of her back country are enough to', u'frighten one, they look so bony.  The town itself is perhaps the', u'dearest place to live in, in all New England.  It is a land of oil,', u'true enough: but not like Canaan; a land, also, of corn and wine.', u'The streets do not run with milk; nor in the spring-time do they pave', u'them with fresh eggs.  Yet, in spite of this, nowhere in all America', u'will you find more patrician-like houses; parks and gardens more', u'opulent, than in New Bedford.  Whence came they? how planted upon', u'this once scraggy scoria of a country?', u'', u'Go and gaze upon the iron emblematical harpoons round yonder lofty', u'mansion, and your question will be answered.  Yes; all these brave', u'houses and flowery gardens came from the Atlantic, Pacific, and', u'Indian oceans.  One and all, they were harpooned and dragged up', u'hither from the bottom of the sea.  Can Herr Alexander perform a feat', u'like that?', u'', u'In New Bedford, fathers, they say, give whales for dowers to their', u'daughters, and portion off their nieces with a few porpoises a-piece.', u'You must go to New Bedford to see a brilliant wedding; for, they', u'say, they have reservoirs of oil in every house, and every night', u'recklessly burn their lengths in spermaceti candles.', u'', u'In summer time, the town is sweet to see; full of fine maples--long', u'avenues of green and gold.  And in August, high in air, the beautiful', u'and bountiful horse-chestnuts, candelabra-wise, proffer the passer-by', u'their tapering upright cones of congregated blossoms.  So omnipotent', u'is art; which in many a district of New Bedford has superinduced', u'bright terraces of flowers upon the barren refuse rocks thrown aside', u"at creation's final day.", u'', u'And the women of New Bedford, they bloom like their own red roses.', u'But roses only bloom in summer; whereas the fine carnation of their', u'cheeks is perennial as sunlight in the seventh heavens.  Elsewhere', u'match that bloom of theirs, ye cannot, save in Salem, where they tell', u'me the young girls breathe such musk, their sailor sweethearts smell', u'them miles off shore, as though they were drawing nigh the odorous', u'Moluccas instead of the Puritanic sands.', u'', u'', u'', u''])]

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# There are a lot of '*' in the text, remove them
chapters_no_stars = chapters.map(lambda (chapter, lines): (
    chapter,
    [ l.replace('*', '') for l in lines ]
))
chapters_no_stars.take(5)

WALW-IAN, to roll, to wallow." --RICHARDSON\'S DICTIONARY', u'', u'KETOS,               GREEK.', u'CETUS,               LATIN.', u'WHOEL,               ANGLO-SAXON.', u'HVALT,               DANISH.', u'WAL,                 DUTCH.', u'HWAL,                SWEDISH.', u'WHALE,               ICELANDIC.', u'WHALE,               ENGLISH.', u'BALEINE,             FRENCH.', u'BALLENA,             SPANISH.', u'PEKEE-NUEE-NUEE,     FEGEE.', u'PEKEE-NUEE-NUEE,     ERROMANGOAN.', u'', u'', u'', u'', u'EXTRACTS (Supplied by a Sub-Sub-Librarian).', u'', u'It will be seen that this mere painstaking burrower and grub-worm of', u'a poor devil of a Sub-Sub appears to have gone through the long', u'Vaticans and street-stalls of the earth, picking up whatever random', u'allusions to whales he could anyways find in any book whatsoever,', u'sacred or profane.  Therefore you must not, in every case at least,', u'take the higgledy-piggledy whale statements, however authentic, in', u'these extracts, for veritable gospel cetology.  Far from it.  As', u'touching the ancient authors generally, as well as the poets here', u'appearing, these extracts are solely valuable or entertaining, as', u"affording a glancing bird's eye view of what has been promiscuously", u'said, thought, fancied, and sung of Leviathan, by many nations and', u'generations, including our own.', u'', u'So fare thee well, poor devil of a Sub-Sub, whose commentator I am.', u'Thou belongest to that hopeless, sallow tribe which no wine of this', u'world will ever warm; and for whom even Pale Sherry would be too', u'rosy-strong; but with whom one sometimes loves to sit, and feel', u'poor-devilish, too; and grow convivial upon tears; and say to them', u'bluntly, with full eyes and empty glasses, and in not altogether', u'unpleasant sadness--Give it up, Sub-Subs! I take it that this part of the', u'bill must have run something like this:', u'', u'', u'"GRAND CONTESTED ELECTION FOR THE PRESIDENCY OF THE UNITED STATES.', u'"WHALING VOYAGE BY ONE ISHMAEL.', u'"BLOODY BATTLE IN AFFGHANISTAN."', u'', u'', u'Though I cannot tell why it was exactly that those stage managers,', u'the Fates, put me down for this shabby part of a whaling voyage, when', u'others were set down for magnificent parts in high tragedies, and', u'short and easy parts in genteel comedies, and jolly parts in', u'farces--though I cannot tell why this was exactly; yet, now that I', u'recall all the circumstances, I think I can see a little into the', u'springs and motives which being cunningly presented to me under', u'various disguises, induced me to set about performing the part I did,', u'besides cajoling me into the delusion that it was a choice resulting', u'from my own unbiased freewill and discriminating judgment.', u'', u'Chief among these motives was the overwhelming idea of the great', u'whale himself. But by dint of much and earnest', u'contemplation, and oft repeated ponderings, and especially by', u'throwing open the little window towards the back of the entry, you at', u'last come to the conclusion that such an idea, however wild, might', u'not be altogether unwarranted.', u'', u'But what most puzzled and confounded you was a long, limber,', u'portentous, black mass of something hovering in the centre of the', u'picture over three blue, dim, perpendicular lines floating in a', u'nameless yeast. And the man that has anything bountifully', u'laughable about him, be sure there is more in that man than you', u'perhaps think for.', u'', u'The bar-room was now full of the boarders who had been dropping in', u'the night previous, and whom I had not as yet had a good look at.', u'They were nearly all whalemen; chief mates, and second mates, and', u'third mates, and sea carpenters, and sea coopers, and sea', u'blacksmiths, and harpooneers, and ship keepers; a brown and brawny', u'company, with bosky beards; an unshorn, shaggy set, all wearing', u'monkey jackets for morning gowns.', u'', u'You could pretty plainly tell how long each one had been ashore.', u"This young fellow's healthy cheek is like a sun-toasted pear in hue,", u'and would seem to smell almost as musky; he cannot have been three', u'days landed from his Indian voyage. They', u'are mostly young, of stalwart frames; fellows who have felled', u'forests, and now seek to drop the axe and snatch the whale-lance.', u'Many are as green as the Green Mountains whence they came.  In some', u'things you would think them but a few hours old.  Look there! that', u'chap strutting round the corner.  He wears a beaver hat and', u'swallow-tailed coat, girdled with a sailor-belt and sheath-knife.', u"Here comes another with a sou'-wester and a bombazine cloak.", u'', u'No town-bred dandy will compare with a country-bred one--I mean a', u'downright bumpkin dandy--a fellow that, in the dog-days, will mow his', u'two acres in buckskin gloves for fear of tanning his hands.  Now when', u'a country dandy like this takes it into his head to make a', u'distinguished reputation, and joins the great whale-fishery, you', u'should see the comical things he does upon reaching the seaport.  In', u'bespeaking his sea-outfit, he orders bell-buttons to his waistcoats;', u'straps to his canvas trowsers.  Ah, poor Hay-Seed! how bitterly will', u'burst those straps in the first howling gale, when thou art driven,', u'straps, buttons, and all, down the throat of the tempest.', u'', u'But think not that this famous town has only harpooneers, cannibals,', u'and bumpkins to show her visitors.  Not at all.  Still New Bedford is', u'a queer place.  Had it not been for us whalemen, that tract of land', u'would this day perhaps have been in as howling condition as the coast', u'of Labrador.  As it is, parts of her back country are enough to', u'frighten one, they look so bony.  The town itself is perhaps the', u'dearest place to live in, in all New England.  It is a land of oil,', u'true enough: but not like Canaan; a land, also, of corn and wine.', u'The streets do not run with milk; nor in the spring-time do they pave', u'them with fresh eggs.  Yet, in spite of this, nowhere in all America', u'will you find more patrician-like houses; parks and gardens more', u'opulent, than in New Bedford.  Whence came they? how planted upon', u'this once scraggy scoria of a country?', u'', u'Go and gaze upon the iron emblematical harpoons round yonder lofty', u'mansion, and your question will be answered.  Yes; all these brave', u'houses and flowery gardens came from the Atlantic, Pacific, and', u'Indian oceans.  One and all, they were harpooned and dragged up', u'hither from the bottom of the sea.  Can Herr Alexander perform a feat', u'like that?', u'', u'In New Bedford, fathers, they say, give whales for dowers to their', u'daughters, and portion off their nieces with a few porpoises a-piece.', u'You must go to New Bedford to see a brilliant wedding; for, they', u'say, they have reservoirs of oil in every house, and every night', u'recklessly burn their lengths in spermaceti candles.', u'', u'In summer time, the town is sweet to see; full of fine maples--long', u'avenues of green and gold.  And in August, high in air, the beautiful', u'and bountiful horse-chestnuts, candelabra-wise, proffer the passer-by', u'their tapering upright cones of congregated blossoms.  So omnipotent', u'is art; which in many a district of New Bedford has superinduced', u'bright terraces of flowers upon the barren refuse rocks thrown aside', u"at creation's final day.", u'', u'And the women of New Bedford, they bloom like their own red roses.', u'But roses only bloom in summer; whereas the fine carnation of their', u'cheeks is perennial as sunlight in the seventh heavens.  Elsewhere', u'match that bloom of theirs, ye cannot, save in Salem, where they tell', u'me the young girls breathe such musk, their sailor sweethearts smell', u'them miles off shore, as though they were drawing nigh the odorous', u'Moluccas instead of the Puritanic sands.', u'', u'', u'', u''])]
